title: Data undermines Jenrick's claim about asylum seekers saying they are children
body:
A claim made in parliament by the immigration minister that up to a fifth of adult male asylum seekers pretend to be children when they arrive in the UK has been undermined by the Home Office's own data, which shows the actual figure is just 1%.

The fact-checking organisation Full Fact has obtained new freedom of information data which shows that between 1 January and 7 November 2022 only around 1% of all males arriving on small boats at Western Jet Foil claimed to be under 18 but were then later found to be over 18.

Full Fact has written to Robert Jenrick asking him to correct the parliamentary record or to provide data which supports his claim.

Last November, Jenrick said in parliament: "At times, up to 20% of the adult males who arrive at Western Jet Foil claim to be under 18, when clearly the number is substantially less than that."

An initial request Full Fact made to Jenrick last November to provide evidence to support the 20% claim or to correct the parliamentary record in accordance with the ministerial code went unanswered. The organisation then submitted a freedom of information request and received the data after several months of delay by the Home Office.

It is not the first time Full Fact has raised concerns about the government's use of immigration statistics. On 7 March 2023, the home secretary, Suella Braverman, accused Labour of leaving a far bigger asylum backlog than the government is currently dealing with. However, when Labour left power in 2010 the backlog was 18,954 and at the end of December 2022 it stood at 161,000.

Full Fact raised concerns with the Office for Statistics Regulation (OSR) about ministers' use of unpublished data and on 21 November the OSR's director general, Ed Humpherson, wrote to Matthew Rycroft, the permanent secretary for the Home Office, to highlight the importance of transparency of statistics.

In the letter Humpherson wrote: "Given the continued public interest in and use of immigration statistics, I urge the Home Office to review ways of working to ensure that the transparent release and use of Home Office data and statistics is the default in future."

The interim chief executive at Full Fact, Andrew Dudfield, said: "Successive ministers have made claims about asylum and immigration which are not backed up by published data. It is the job of the prime minister, the home secretary, and the minister for immigration to communicate accurately and responsibly with the public on important issues.

"Repeated failure to be transparent makes proper democratic scrutiny impossible. It's vital we're all given access to the information behind the claims made by ministers when they make them, and that any data quoted publicly is freely available. Public trust in politics is low. Our democracy depends on good information and right now we have a system that operates as if transparency and accountability are optional."

The Home Office has been approached for comment.

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article explicitly refers to Full Fact as a fact‑checking organisation, matching the description of a non‑profit, independent group.

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article explicitly names "Full Fact" as a fact‑checking organisation and describes its activities (obtaining FOI data, writing to the immigration minister, raising concerns with the OSR). This matches the Wikidata entity’s name, description, and UK-based charity status. No other entity with a similar name is mentioned, and the context (fact‑checking, FOI requests, political scrutiny) aligns perfectly with the Wikidata profile.
reasoning.statement_assessment: Full Fact is quoted through its interim chief executive, Andrew Dudfield, who says: "Successive ministers have made claims about asylum and immigration which are not backed up by published data…" This is a direct statement attributed to a representative of the organisation.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: Highly plausible: a chief executive of a fact‑checking charity would publicly critique ministers’ use of data and advocate for transparency.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions between the article’s depiction of Full Fact and the Wikidata entity. The statements are consistent with the organisation’s mission.

This matches the Wikidata entity’s description (UK lawyer and politician who served as Home Secretary from 2022‑2023). No other person named Suella Braverman is mentioned, and the context (role, time period, UK government) aligns perfectly with the Wikidata profile. Therefore the entity is present and correctly identified.
reasoning.statement_assessment: Suella Braverman is attributed with a statement: "On 7 March 2023, the home secretary, Suella Braverman, accused Labour of leaving a far bigger asylum backlog than the government is currently dealing with." The article does not provide a direct quote but clearly attributes the claim to her. Thus, she is making a statement in the article.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the Home Secretary to make such a statement about asylum backlogs, as this falls within her ministerial responsibilities. The timing (March 2023) coincides with her tenure, further supporting plausibility.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions are found between the article’s depiction of Suella Braverman and the Wikidata entity. The role, title, and context all match.

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article explicitly names "OSR's director general, Ed Humpherson" and refers to him as the writer of a letter to the Home Office. This matches the Wikidata entity Edward Humpherson (director general of the Office for Statistics Regulation) in both name and role. No other individual named Ed/Edward Humpherson is mentioned, and the context (statistical regulation, transparency of immigration data) aligns with the entity’s description as a civil servant and director general of the OSR.
reasoning.statement_assessment: Ed Humpherson is quoted directly in the letter he wrote: "Given the continued public interest in and use of immigration statistics, I urge the Home Office to review ways of working to ensure that the transparent release and use of Home Office data and statistics is the default in future." This is a clear statement attributed to him.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the director general of the OSR to make such a statement about the transparency of statistical data used by the Home Office, as this falls squarely within the OSR’s remit to oversee the quality and integrity of official statistics.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions are present. The article’s description of Humpherson’s role and the content of his statement are consistent with the Wikidata profile.
